message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gross and microscopic appearance of the patient's colonic tissue indicates that the patient has familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder, meaning that each child of an affected individual has a 50% chance of inheriting the disease-causing mutation. Therefore, the likelihood that this patient’s children will develop FAP is 50%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the colon tissue. FAP is an autosomal dominant condition, which means that each child of a patient with FAP has a 50% chance of inheriting the condition. The partner being a carrier is not relevant as FAP is not a recessive condition. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) 50%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gross and microscopic appearance suggests familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), an autosomal dominant disorder. If the patient has FAP, there is a 50% chance his children will have inherited the mutated gene and develop the condition. The fact that his partner is not a carrier is irrelevant because FAP is a dominant disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gross appearance of the patient's colonic tissue with adenomas suggests familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder, which means that there is a 50% chance that each child of an affected parent will inherit the gene mutation and develop the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gross and microscopic appearance of the patient's colonic tissues indicate the presence of colorectal adenomatous polyposis (FAP), an autosomal dominant genetic condition. The likelihood of passing on the condition to the children of an affected individual is 50%. The patient’s partner being a carrier or not does not impact this probability as it is driven by the affected individual's own genotype.

FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder and each child of an affected individual has a 50% chance of inheriting the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient most likely has Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP), based on the presence of multiple polyps in the colon. FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder, which means that affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing on the mutation to their children.
